summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ OIG Senior Special Agent and Special Agent with a Bureau of Prisons employee, a Supervisory Correctional Systems Specialist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, as part of the OIG investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The interview focuses on the witness's role, knowledge of procedures, and events surrounding the transfer of Epstein's cellmate and Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the OIG investigation into his death by suicide at the MCC in August 2019. The interview discusses the circumstances around his death, including the removal of his cellmate.

connections.description: Tartaglione was Epstein's cellmate in the SHU. His transfer out of the MCC on August 9, 2019, left Epstein alone in the cell.
Both were correctional officers assigned to the SHU at the time of Epstein's death. The witness was tasked with conducting wellness checks on both after the incident.
As the R&D movement officer, Tiffany would have been responsible for processing Tartaglione's transfer paperwork and movement on August 9, 2019.
Larry was the witness's supervisor, the Case Manager Coordinator (CMC), at the time relevant to the investigation.

events.title: Transfer of Nicholas Tartaglione
events.description: Inmate Nicholas Tartaglione, Jeffrey Epstein's cellmate, was transferred from the MCC SHU to a GEO facility. Emails from the U.S. Marshals Service scheduled the transfer for this date. His removal left Epstein without a cellmate.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the MCC, an apparent suicide by hanging. The discovery was made in the early morning hours.

events.title: Alleged prior suicide attempt
events.description: The OIG agents ask the witness about an alleged first suicide attempt by Jeffrey Epstein on this date. The witness states they only learned about it afterwards.

events.title: OIG Interview
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with a BOP Supervisory Correctional Systems Specialist at the MCC as part of its investigation into Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York, New York
GEO facility (contract facility for federal inmates)
keyFacts: The witness, a BOP supervisor in Receiving and Discharge (R&D), had no direct interaction with Jeffrey Epstein during his stay at the MCC.

The witness clarifies that an inmate marked 'WAB' (With All Belongings) on a transfer list should be known to staff as 'not coming back,' countering claims that SHU staff might have thought Epstein's cellmate was only going to court.

The witness states that internal daily court/transfer rosters are printed, distributed, and then discarded/deleted daily, with no long-term retention, making it difficult to reconstruct what was documented about Tartaglione's transfer.
The witness denies any knowledge of an inmate being placed on a 'dry cell' watch in the R&D area on August 9, 2019, stating they would not allow it as R&D does not watch inmates.

The witness heard rumors about staff not conducting rounds/counts and falsifying records but has no firsthand knowledge, and suggests more training and staffing as systemic issues that may have contributed to Epstein's death.
